Tronox LLC's Hamilton Facility is an OSHA VPP (Voluntary Protection Program) Star site that has a standing policy, Commitment to Environmental Stewardship.  We are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and environmentally responsible manner.  Several programs have been developed and implemented to address accidental release prevention and emergency response planning to help ensure the safety of our employees, contractors, and neighbors and protection of the environment.  The Hamilton Facility has developed and implemented an Emergency Response Program for protecting public health and the environment. 

 

The Tronox Hamilton Facility is situated on approximately 3,000 acres in Monroe County, near the town of Hamilton, Mississippi, and produces titanium dioxide (TiO2) pigment.  Chlorine is used to manufacture TiO2, and as a processing aid in the cooling towers and water treatment systems.  Titanium Tetrachloride (TiCl4) is produced as an intermediate product during the pigment production process.  



The facility has prepared a worst case scenario for chlorine and an alternative release scenario for titanium tetrachloride.



As required by RMP, the toxic worst case scenario involves emptying a vessel containing 180,000 pounds of chlorine over a period of 10 minutes under meteorological conditions of 105F and 73% relative humidity at night.  The model predicted the chlorine would reach the endpoint concentration after traveling 4.4 miles.



The alternative scenario for titanium tetrachloride was assumed to consist of the release of 2 selas preheaters.  This scenario was modeled with EPA RMP* Comp, and it indicated an endpoint concentration would be reached at 0.9 miles.



The facility has taken numerous steps to prevent releases from its operations.  Some of these include installation of pressure relief valves and excess flow valves on storage tanks.  Water deluge systems and diking of tanks and vessels have been utilized.  Standard

Our ER Plan is site-specific and has been shared with the Monroe County EPC.  Facility employees are trained to respond to emergencies as described in the emergency response plan, including routine drills.  Onsite HazMat Fire/Rescue team members are trained in the use of the necessary personal protective equipment needed to respond to accidental releases of all substances at the facility.  EMR/EMT team members are trained in the proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures.  In addition, the facility has a full-time Occupational Nurse onsite that provides medical monitoring for all employees.



Tronox is committed to continuously improving our safety, health and environmental performance including the prevention of accidental releases.
